content.text:
# Timeline of New Mexico history

This timeline is a chronology of significant events in the history of the US State of New Mexico and the historical area that is now occupied by the state.
__NOTOC__
2020s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2022||align=center|November 8||In the 2022 General Election, New Mexico voters elect elect Gabe Vasquez and re-elect Melanie Stansbury and Teresa Leger Fernandez to the United States House of Representatives. Voters re-elect Governor Michelle Lujan Grisham. Democrats retain control of the New Mexico Legislature.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2021||align=center|June 1||Melanie Stansbury wins the special congressional replacement election to replace Deb Haaland as the U.S. representative for New Mexico's 1st Congressional District.
|-
|align=center|May 16||Deb Haaland assumes office as the United States Secretary of the Interior, the first Native American to serve as a U.S. Cabinet Secretary.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2020||align=center|November 3||In the 2020 general election, New Mexico voters elect five U.S. presidential electors for Joe Biden, elect Ben Ray Luján as new U.S. senator, re-elect Deb Haaland and elect Yvette Herrell and Teresa Leger Fernandez as U.S. representatives.  Democrats retain control of the New Mexico Legislature.
|-
|align=center|April 2||The 2020 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later tabulated as 2,117,522, a 2.83% increase since the 2010 United States census. New Mexico remains the 36st most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|-
|align=center|March 1|| COVID-19 has affected in New Mexico, which impacted the economy, culture, business, and the people of this state.
|}
2010s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2019||align=center|December  20||U.S. President Donald Trump signs the National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2020 which creates White Sands National Park from White Sands National Monument.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Michelle Lujan Grisham assumes office as the thirty-second Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|2015||align=center|November 10||The National Park Service creates the Manhattan Project National Historical Park.
|-
|align=center|October 22||Dianna Duran resigns as New Mexico Secretary of State amid investigations of corruption.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2014||align=center|May 21||U.S. President Barack Obama issues an executive order creating Organ Mountains–Desert Peaks National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2013||align=center|May 16||The City of Rio Communities is incorporated.
|-
|align=center|March 25||U.S. President Barack Obama issues an executive order creating Rio Grande del Norte National Monument.
|-
|align=center|January 3||Martin Heinrich takes office as the junior New Mexico U.S. Senator.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2011||align=center|January 1||Susana Martinez assumes office as the thirty-first Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2010||align=center|April 1||The 2010 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 2,059,179, an increase of 13.2% since the 2000 United States census. New Mexico remains the 36th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
2000s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2009||align=center|January 3||Tom Udall takes office as the junior New Mexico U.S. Senator.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2003||align=center|January 1||Bill Richardson assumes office as the thirtieth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2002||align=center|December 4||U.S. President George W. Bush signs An Act to amend the National Trails System Act to designate the Old Spanish Trail as a National Historic Trail creating the Old Spanish National Historic Trail.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|2001||align=center|January 17||U.S. President Bill Clinton issues an executive order creating Kasha-Katuwe Tent Rocks National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|2000||align=center|October 13||U.S. President Bill Clinton signs An Act to amend the National Trails System Act to designate El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro as a National Historic Trail, creating El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro National Historic Trail.
|-
|align=center|July 25||U.S. President Bill Clinton signs An Act to authorize the acquisition of the Valles Caldera, to provide for an effective land and wildlife management program for this resource within the Department of Agriculture, and for other purposes, creating the Valles Caldera National Preserve.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 2000 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 1,819,046, an increase of 20.1% since the 1990 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 36th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1990s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1998||align=center|August 18||U.S. President Bill Clinton appoints Bill Richardson the ninth United States Secretary of Energy.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1997||align=center|February 18||U.S. President Bill Clinton appoints Bill Richardson the twenty-first United States Ambassador to the United Nations.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1995||align=center|January 1||Gary Johnson assumes office as the twenty-ninth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1992||align=center|December 14||The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) designates Taos Pueblo as a World Heritage Site.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1991||align=center|July 2||The National Park Service changes the name of Pecos National Monument to Pecos National Historical Park.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Bruce King assumes office as the twenty-eighth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1990||align=center|June 27||U.S. President George H. W. Bush issues a proclamation creating Petroglyph National Monument.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1990 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 1,515,069, an increase of 16.2% since the 1980 United States census. New Mexico remains the 37th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1980s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1988||align=center|October 28||The National Park Service changes the name of Salinas National Monument to Salinas Pueblo Missions National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=4|1987||align=center|December 31||U.S. President Ronald Reagan signs An Act to establish the El Malpais National Monument and the El Malpais National Conservation Area in the State of New Mexico, to authorize the Masau Trail, and for other purposes, creating El Malpais National Monument and changing the name of Capulin Mountain National Monument to Capulin Volcano National Monument.
|-
|align=center|December 11||The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization (UNESCO) designates the Chaco Culture World Heritage Site.  The Chaco Culture World Heritage Site includes Chaco Culture National Historical Park, Aztec Ruins National Monument, and several smaller Chaco sites managed by the Bureau of Land Management.
|-
|align=center|May 8||U.S. President Ronald Reagan signs An Act to amend the National Trails System Act to designate the Santa Fe Trail as a National Historic Trail, creating the Santa Fe National Historic Trail.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Garrey Carruthers assumes office as the twenty-seventh Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1983||align=center|January 1||Toney Anaya assumes office as the twenty-sixth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1981||align=center|June 19||Cibola County, the thirty-third and newest county, is created from the western part of Valencia County.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1980||align=center|December 19||U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs An Act to designate certain National Forest System lands in the State of New Mexico for inclusion in the National Wilderness Preservation System, and for other purposes, that changes the name of Chaco Canyon National Monument to Chaco Culture National Historical Park, and changes the name of Gran Quivira National Monument to Salinas National Monument.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1980 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 1,302,894, an increase of 28.1% since the 1970 United States census. New Mexico remains the 37th most populous of the 50 U.S. states but gains a 3rd Congressional District.
|}
1970s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1979||align=center|January 1||Bruce King assumes office as the twenty-fifth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1978||align=center|November 10||U.S. President Jimmy Carter signs the National Parks and Recreation Act of 1978 creating the Continental Divide National Scenic Trail.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1976||align=center|July 4||The State of New Mexico celebrates the Bicentennial of the United States of America.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1975||align=center|January 1||Jerry Apodaca assumes office as the twenty-fourth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1971||align=center|January 1||Bruce King assumes office as the twenty-third Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1970||align=center|April 1||The 1970 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 1,017,055, an increase of 6.9% since the 1960 United States census. New Mexico remains the 37th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1960s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1969||align=center|March 4||New Mexico creates its 2nd Congressional District to replace its At-large Congressional seat.  This congressional district remains to the present.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1968||align=center|December 2||U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs An Act to establish a national trails system, and for other purposes, creating the National Trails System.
|-
|align=center|July 1||U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson signs An Act to establish a national trails system, and for other purposes, creating the National Trails System.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1967||align=center|June 5||Reies Tijerina leads an armed raid on the Rio Arriba County Courthouse in Tierra Amarilla.
|-
|align=center|January 1||David Cargo assumes office as the twenty-second Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1965||align=center|June 28||U.S. President Lyndon B. Johnson issues a proclamation creating Pecos National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1963||align=center|January 1||Jack M. Campbell assumes office as the twenty-first Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1962||align=center|November 30||Lieutenant Governor Tom Bolack assumes office as the twentieth Governor of the State of New Mexico upon the resignation of Governor Edwin L. Mechem.
|-
|align=center|November 18||Dennis Chavez, United States Senator since 1934, dies during his fifth term in the Senate.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1961||align=center|January 1||Edwin L. Mechem assumes office as the nineteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1960||align=center|November 8||The State of New Mexico amends its Constitution changing the name of New Mexico College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts to New Mexico State University.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1960 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 951,023, an increase of 39.6% since the 1950 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 37th most populous of the 50 U.S. states.
|}
1950s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1959||align=center|January 1||John Burroughs assumes office as the eighteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1957||align=center|January 1||Edwin L. Mechem assumes office as the seventeenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1955||align=center|January 1||John F. Simms assumes office as the sixteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1954||align=center|June 28||U.S. President Dwight D. Eisenhower issues a proclamation creating Fort Union National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1951||align=center|January 1||Edwin L. Mechem assumes office as the fifteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1950||align=center|August 28||U.S. President Harry S. Truman issues a Public Land Order abolishing Mesilla National Forest.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1950 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 681,187, an increase of 28.1% since the 1940 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 39th most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1940s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1947||align=center|January 1||Thomas J. Mabry assumes office as the fourteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1945||align=center|September 2||World War II ends as the Empire of Japan formally surrenders.
|-
|align=center|July 18||The U.S. Army's Manhattan Project conducts the Trinity test, the first detonation of a nuclear weapon.  The test is conducted in Socorro County on the Alamogordo Bombing Range.
|-
|align=center|May 8||The war in Europe ends as the Greater German Empire formally surrenders.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1944||align=center|April 6||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt issues a Public Land Order creating Mesilla National Forest. (Abolished August 28, 1950.)
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1943||align=center|January 1||John J. Dempsey assumes office as the thirteenth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1941||align=center|December 11||The United States declares war on the German Reich and the Italian Empire.
|-
|align=center|December 8||The United States declares war on the Empire of Japan and enters World War II.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1940||align=center|April 1||The 1940 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 531,818, an increase of 25.6% since the 1930 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 41st most populous of the 48 U.S. states and gains a 2nd Congressional seat.
|}
1930s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1939||align=center|January 1||John E. Miles assumes office as the twelfth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1937||align=center|November 3||The United States Department of Agriculture creates Kiowa National Grassland.
|-
|align=center|July 22||U.S. President Franklin D. Roosevelt signs An Act to create the Farmers' Home Corporation, to promote more secure occupancy of farms and farm homes, to correct the economic instability resulting from some present forms of farm tenancy, and for other purposes, also known as the Bankhead-Jones Farm Tenant Act.
|-
|align=center|spring ||Bluewater State Park, New Mexico's first state park, opens.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1935||align=center|January 1||Clyde Tingley assumes office as the eleventh Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1933||align=center|September 25||Lieutenant Governor Andrew W. Hockenhull assumes office as the tenth Governor of the State of New Mexico upon the death of Governor Arthur Seligman.
|-
|align=center|January 18||U.S. President Herbert Hoover issues a proclamation creating White Sands National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1932||align=center|August ||Edgar Billings Howard begins excavating the Blackwater Locality No. 1 archaeological site discovered in 1929 by Ridgely Whiteman near Clovis. Blackwater Locality No. 1 becomes the type site for Clovis culture.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1931||align=center|December 3||U.S. President Herbert Hoover issues an executive order creating Cibola National Forest.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Arthur Seligman assumes office as the ninth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1930||align=center|May 14||U.S. President Herbert Hoover signs An Act to establish the Carlsbad Caverns National Park in the State of New Mexico, and for other purposes, creating Carlsbad Caverns National Park from Carlsbad Caverns National Monument.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1930 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 423,317, an increase of 17.5% since the 1920 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 43rd most populous of the 48 U.S. states.
|}
1920s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1929||align=center| ||Nineteen-year-old Ridgley Whiteman discovers Paleo-Indian artifacts at Blackwater Draw near Clovis.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1928||align=center|July 2||U.S. President Calvin Coolidge issues an executive order enlarging Aztec Ruin National Monument and changing the name to Aztec Ruins National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1927||align=center|January 1||Richard C. Dillon assumes office as the eighth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1925||align=center|January 1||Arthur T. Hannett assumes office as the seventh Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1924||align=center|June 2||U.S. President Calvin Coolidge signs An Act To authorize the Secretary of the Interior to issue certificates of citizenship to Indians, also known as the Indian Citizenship Act of 1924, finally granting full United States Citizenship to all Native Americans born in the United States.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1923||align=center|October 25||U.S. President Calvin Coolidge issues a proclamation creating Carlsbad Caverns National Monument.
|-
|align=center|January 24||U.S. President Warren G. Harding issues a proclamation creating Aztec Ruin National Monument.
|-
|align=center|January 1||James F. Hinkle assumes office as the sixth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1921||align=center|March 4||Harding County is created on the same day its namesake, Warren G. Harding, is inaugurated as President of the United States.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Merritt C. Mechem assumes office as the fifth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1920||align=center|April 1||The 1920 United States census enumerates the population of the State of New Mexico, later determined to be 360,350, an increase of 10.1% since the 1910 United States census. New Mexico becomes the 43rd most populous of the 48 U.S. states
|}
1910s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1919||align=center|January 1||Octaviano Ambrosio Larrazolo assumes office as the fourth Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1918||align=center|November 11||An armistice halts the Great War.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1917||align=center|April 6||The United States declares war on the German Empire and enters the Great War.
|-
|align=center|February 18||Lieutenant Governor Washington Lindsey assumes office as the third Governor of the State of New Mexico upon the death of Governor Ezequiel Cabeza De Baca.
|-
|align=center|January 1||Ezequiel Cabeza De Baca assumes office as the second Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1916||align=center|August 25||U.S. President Woodrow Wilson signs An Act To establish a National Park Service, and for other purposes.
|-
|align=center|August 9||U.S. President Woodrow Wilson issues a proclamation creating Capulin Mountain National Monument.
|-
|align=center|February 11||U.S. President Woodrow Wilson issues a proclamation creating Bandelier National Monument.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1915||align=center|April 6||U.S. President Woodrow Wilson issues an executive order creating Santa Fe National Forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1912||align=center|January 14||William C. McDonald assumes office as the first Governor of the State of New Mexico.
|-  style="background-color:#FFDDDD;"
|align=center|January 6||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues Proclamation 1175: Admitting New Mexico to the Union. The Territory of New Mexico becomes the State of New Mexico, the 47th U.S. state.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1910||align=center|June 20||U.S. President William Howard Taft signs An Act to enable the people of New Mexico to form a constitution and state government and be admitted into the Union on an equal footing with the original States; and to enable the people of Arizona to form a constitution and state government and be admitted into the Union on an equal footing with the original States.
|-
|align=center|April 1||The 1910 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of New Mexico, later determined to be 327,301, an increase of 67.6% since the 1900 United States census. New Mexico becomes the most populous of the four U.S. territories.
|-
|align=center|March 1||U.S. President William Howard Taft appoints William J. Mills the eighteenth (and last) Governor of the Territory of New Mexico.
|}
1900s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1909||align=center|November 1||U.S. President William Howard Taft issues a proclamation creating Gran Quivira National Monument.
|-
|align=center|March 2||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Zuni National Forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1908||align=center|July 2||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues executive orders creating Alamo National Forest and Pecos National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 26||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues an executive order creating Carson National Forest.
|-
|align=center|June 18||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Datil National Forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=8|1907||align=center|November 16||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Gila Cliff Dwellings National Monument.
|-
|align=center|April 24||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Sacramento National Forest.
|-
|align=center|April 20||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt appoints George Curry the seventeenth Governor of the Territory of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center|April 19||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Guadalupe National Forest.
|-
|align=center|March 16||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation abolishing the Portales Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|March 11||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating Chaco Canyon National Monument.
|-
|align=center|March 1||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Las Animas Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|February 6||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Big Burros Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=8|1906||align=center|December 8||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating El Morro National Monument.
|-
|align=center|November 7||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Taos Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|November 6||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Manzano Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|November 5||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues proclamations creating the Gallinas Forest Reserve, the Magdalena Forest Reserve, the Peloncillo Forest Reserve, and the San Mateo Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|October 5||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Mount Taylor Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|June 16||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt signs An Act to enable the people of Oklahoma and of the Indian Territory to form a constitution and State government and be admitted into the Union on an equal footing with the original States; and to enable the people of New Mexico and of Arizona to form a constitution and State government and be admitted into the Union on an equal footing with the original States.
|-
|align=center|June 8||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt signs An Act For the preservation of American antiquities, also known as the Antiquities Act of 1906, giving the President of the United States the authority to create national monuments on federal lands to protect significant natural, cultural, or scientific features.
|-
|align=center|January 10||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt appoints Herbert James Hagerman the sixteenth Governor of the Territory of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1905||align=center|October 12||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Jemez Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center|October 3||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Portales Forest Reserve. (Abolished March 16, 1907.)
|-
|align=center|July 21||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Gila Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1902||align=center|July 26||U.S. President Theodore Roosevelt issues a proclamation creating the Lincoln Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1900||align=center|April 1||The 1900 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of New Mexico, later determined to be 195,310, an increase of 21.9% since the 1890 United States census. New Mexico becomes the second most populous of the five U.S. territories.
|}
1890s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1899||align=center|March 2||U.S. President William McKinley issues a proclamation creating the Gila River Forest Reserve.
|-
|align=center rowspan=3|1898||align=center|December 10||The United States of America and the Kingdom of Spain sign the Treaty of Paris of 1898 to end the Spanish–American War.
|-
|align=center|August 12||The United States of America and the Kingdom of Spain sign a Protocol of Peace.
|-
|align=center|April 23||The Kingdom of Spain declares war on the United States of America.  The United States declares war on Spain two days later.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1897||align=center|June 2||U.S. President William McKinley appoints Miguel Antonio Otero the fifteenth Governor of the Territory of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1893||align=center|April ||U.S. President Grover Cleveland appoints William Taylor Thornton the fourteenth Governor of the Territory of New Mexico.
|-
|align=center rowspan=1|1892||align=center|January 11||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison issues a proclamation creating the Pecos River Forest Reserve, the third United States National Forest.
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1891||align=center|March 3||U.S. President Benjamin Harrison signs An act to repeal timber-culture laws, and for other purposes, also known as the Forest Reserve Act of 1891, giving the President of the United States the authority to create protected national forests on federal lands.
|-
|align=center|winter ||The New Mexico Territorial Agriculture College changes it name to the New Mexico College of Agriculture and Mechanic Arts
|-
|align=center rowspan=2|1890||align=center|April 1||The 1890 United States census enumerates the population of the Territory of New Mexico, later determined to be 160,282, an increase of 34.1% since the 1880 United States census. New Mexico becomes the third most populous of the six U.S. territories.
|-
|align=center|January 21||The New Mexico Territorial Agriculture College opens at the former Las Cruces College.
|}
1880s
{|class="wikitable" style="width:100%;"
!style="width:6%"|Year||style="width:8%"|Date||style="width:86%"|Event
|-

|align=center|1682||align=center|April 9||René-Robert Cavelier, Sieur de La Salle, claims the Mississippi River and its watershed for the Kingdom of France and names the region La Louisiane in honor of King Louis XIV.  The Mississippi Basin is later determined to be the fourth most extensive on Earth and includes lands inhabited by hundreds of thousands of native peoples and lands previously claimed by Spain, France, and England.  The Louisiane claim includes the northeast portion the future State of New Mexico in the Mississippi River watershed.  This will set up a rivalry among native peoples, France, Spain, and eventually the United States in the area.

|align=center|1598||align=center|July 12||Don Juan de Oñate Salazar establishes the New Spain (Nueva España) colony of Santa Fe de Nuevo Méjico at the village of San Juan de los Caballeros adjacent to the Ohkay Owingeh Pueblo at the confluence of the Rio Grande (río Bravo) and the río Chama. He claims the sea and all adjacent lands for the Queen of Castile.  This includes the portion of the future State of New Mexico west of the Continental Divide of the Americas.

|align=center|1493||align=center|May 5||Pope Alexander VI (born Roderic de Borja in Valencia) issues the papal bull Inter caetera which splits the non-Christian world into two-halves.  The eastern half goes to the King of Portugal for his exploration, conquest, conversion, and exploitation.  The western half (including all of North America) goes to the Queen of Castile and the King of Aragon for their exploration, conquest, conversion, and exploitation.  The indigenous peoples of the Americas have no idea that any of these people exist.
|-
|align=center|1492||align=center|October 12||Genoese seaman Cristòffa Cómbo (Christopher Columbus) leading an expedition for Queen Isabella I of Castile lands on the Lucayan island of Guanahani that he renames San Salvador.  This begins the Spanish conquest of the Americas.
|}
